content_scrubbed:
I was deciding between Cal and Michigan, so what I have to say won't be particularly relevant to picking between Cal and a private school. My decision at the time mostly came down to ranking (lol), but I can honestly say that I've had a great time here. I'm not someone who gets homesick easily, but that might be different for you. A lot of my friends are also out-of-state, and none of them have ever said anything about missing home/feeling homesick. With how big this school is, it[.] not all that hard to find a community that you feel comfortable with.

Here[.] how I see Cal stacking up with Duke. Cal[.] student body is huge (so it[.] hard to categorize people) and 40% Asian. I'm an Asian-American who grew up in an area without a lot of Asians, but it was actually kind of cool to come here and be with other Asians. Of course, on this front, *your mileage may vary*. It[.] not like this campus is anti-(insert other racial group here), but I can only imagine that it might be hard to adjust socially if you're a member of an under-represented group. With that being said, there are tons of community groups here that do a great job of making everyone feel welcome, and they seem to have a lot of fun.

Our sports teams are pretty decent compared to most other top schools, but Duke has us handily beat, at least on the basketball front. 

I haven't found big class sizes to be a problem, personally. Because most college classes use lectures and aren't discussion-oriented, having more people really doesn't make a difference. If you really, really enjoyed interacting with your teachers in high school, then I think class sizes at most colleges (excluding liberal_arts colleges) would be a little bothersome, at least if you're studying something in STEM.
